hints_html: Calculate \(f''(x)\) by differentiating \(f'(x)\). How can you use the information about \(f(1)\) to find \(f'(1)\) and then \(f''(1)\)?
hints_latex:
Calculate $f''(x)$ by differentiating $f'(x)$. How can you use the
information about $f(1)$ to find $f'(1)$ and then $f''(1)$?
hints_raw: Calculate <math>f''(x)</math> by differentiating <math>f'(x)</math>.  How can you use the information about <math>f(1)</math> to find <math>f'(1)</math> and then <math>f''(1)</math>?
question: 1 (f)
sols_html:
Taking the derivative of the given equation yields

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx} f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \Big(x\big[f(x)\big]^2+x^2\Big) \\ f''(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \Big(x\big[f(x)\big]^2\Big)+\frac{d}{dx}\Big(x^2\Big) \\ &= \big[f(x)\big]^2 + x \big[2f(x)f'(x)\big]+2x \end{aligned}\]

When x=1, f is equal to 2, so

\[\begin{aligned} f''(1) &= \big[f(1)\big]^2 + (1) \big[2f(1)f'(1)\big]+2(1) \\ &= \big[2\big]^2 + \big[2(2)f'(1)\big]+2 \\ &= 6 + 4f'(1) .\end{aligned}\]

We need the first derivative of f at x = 1. Using the expression we are given for the derivative of f,

\[\begin{aligned} f'(1) &= (1)\big[f(1)\big]^2+(1)^2\\ &=2^2+1\\ &=5.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} f''(1) &= 6 + 4f'(1) \\ &= 6 + 4(5) \\ &= 26.\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
Taking the derivative of the given equation yields

\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dx} f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \Big(x\big[f(x)\big]^2+x^2\Big) \\
 f''(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \Big(x\big[f(x)\big]^2\Big)+\frac{d}{dx}\Big(x^2\Big) \\
&= \big[f(x)\big]^2 + x \big[2f(x)f'(x)\big]+2x 
\end{align*} When \emph{x}=1, \emph{f} is equal to 2, so

\begin{align*}
f''(1) 
&= \big[f(1)\big]^2 + (1) \big[2f(1)f'(1)\big]+2(1) \\
&= \big[2\big]^2 + \big[2(2)f'(1)\big]+2 \\
&= 6 + 4f'(1) .
\end{align*} We need the first derivative of \emph{f} at \emph{x} = 1.
Using the expression we are given for the derivative of \emph{f},

\begin{align*}
f'(1) 
&= (1)\big[f(1)\big]^2+(1)^2\\
&=2^2+1\\
&=5.
\end{align*} Therefore,

\begin{align*}
f''(1) 
&= 6 + 4f'(1) \\
&= 6 + 4(5) \\
&= 26.
\end{align*}

Taking the derivative of the given equation yields

:<math>\begin{align}
\frac{d}{dx} f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \Big(x\big[f(x)\big]^2+x^2\Big) \\
 f''(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \Big(x\big[f(x)\big]^2\Big)+\frac{d}{dx}\Big(x^2\Big) \\
&= \big[f(x)\big]^2 + x \big[2f(x)f'(x)\big]+2x \\
\end{align}
</math>
When ''x''=1, ''f'' is equal to 2, so
:<math>\begin{align}
 f''(1) 
&= \big[f(1)\big]^2 + (1) \big[2f(1)f'(1)\big]+2(1) \\
&= \big[2\big]^2 + \big[2(2)f'(1)\big]+2 \\
&= 6 + 4f'(1) .\\
\end{align}
</math>
We need the first derivative of ''f'' at ''x'' = 1. Using the expression we are given for the derivative of ''f'',

:<math>\begin{align}f'(1) 
&= (1)\big[f(1)\big]^2+(1)^2\\
&=2^2+1\\
&=5.
\end{align}</math>
Therefore,
:<math>\begin{align}
 f''(1) 
&= 6 + 4f'(1) \\
&= 6 + 4(5) \\
&= 26.
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Consider a function \(f\) that satisfies

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) = x\big[f(x)\big]^2+x^2.\end{aligned}\]

Evaluate

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f''(1)\end{aligned}\]

if

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(1) = 2.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Consider a function <math>f</math> that satisfies 

:<math>f'(x) = x\big[f(x)\big]^2+x^2.</math>

Evaluate 

:<math>\displaystyle f''(1)</math> 

if 

:<math>\displaystyle f(1) = 2.</math>
